subject: Re : [junit] I wana be move from the list
msgSnippet: Hello, I m trying to be move from the list. Can some one tell me please what I m supposing to or how   can  I do this? I look for the link where I can
messageBody:
Hello,
I'm trying to be move from the list. Can some one tell me please what I'm supposing to or how can I do this?
I look for the link where I can unsubscribe. I didn't found it.
Thanks in advance for your Help about.



















Ne rien dire pour nuire ,ne pas se taire pour plaire


Empereur Yollson


Lessingstr 43


76135 Karlsruhe



----- Message d'origine ----
De : J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...>
À : junit@yahoogroups.com
Envoyé le : Jeudi, 26 Octobre 2006, 14h01mn 28s
Objet : Re: [junit] Can anyone help me see how to usefully work with JUnit in a big project, please?

Tracey Annison wrote:

> I'm completely bewildered by how anyone writing anything larger than
> 100 lines or so gets a benefit from doing this. You clearly ARE, but
> I just don't understand how... I must be missing something!
>
> So, given the sort of work we're doing, and the kind of structure
> I've tried to describe, can anyone out there tell me how I've gone so
> far off track here? Or give me some real examples of quick, useful
> test classes on stuff like this?
> I just KNOW that I must be doing it all wrong, but I can't seem to
> find any real-world examples of how to do it right on this scale. Any
> help would be gratefully recieved!

I tried to read it all, I really did, but I got lost. :) I understand.
I've written "Help!" letters that long and longer.

It sounds like you have a big application and you want to test it, but
so many things have direct dependencies on so many other things that you
can't take a piece of it and test it without involving the rest. Did I
get that right?

Two books:

"Working Effectively with Legacy Code"
"JUnit Recipes"

I wrote one of them, so I understand if you don't trust my endorsement.

Read those, then come back with some specific questions. I promise they
will help you.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains ca
Your guide to software craftsmanship
JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
